**Itlachiayaque** is an [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") introduced in [L](/wiki/L_\(person\) "L (person)")'s Itlachiayaque Patch against [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), where it acts as a replacement for the [Archeologist](/wiki/Archeologist "Archeologist") [quest artifact](/wiki/Quest_artifact "Quest artifact"), [the Orb of Detection](/wiki/The_Orb_of_Detection "The Orb of Detection"). As implemented in the original patch, it is an [intelligent artifact](/wiki/Intelligent_artifact "Intelligent artifact") that is [lawful](/wiki/Lawful "Lawful") for wishing purposes, and its [base item](/wiki/Base_item "Base item") is a [shield of reflection](/wiki/Shield_of_reflection "Shield of reflection").

As several variants implement the Itlachiayaque patch, the appearance and functions of the artifact vary from version to version - the artifact as presented by the patch appears in [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack").

[ ]

## Contents

  - [5.4 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [6 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

## Generation

In the original patch, Itlachiayaque is generated along with the [Bell of Opening](/wiki/Bell_of_Opening "Bell of Opening") atop the [altar](/wiki/Altar "Altar") to [Huhetotl](/wiki/Huhetotl "Huhetotl") where the [Minion of Huhetotl](/wiki/Minion_of_Huhetotl "Minion of Huhetotl") is placed at level creation: the patch also adds four possible locations for the square that the altar, Minion and both items generate on.

## Description

While carried, Itlachiayaque confers [ESP](/wiki/ESP "ESP"), [fire resistance](/wiki/Fire_resistance "Fire resistance") and [half spell damage](/wiki/Half_spell_damage "Half spell damage"). While worn, it confers [reflection](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection") as a normal shield of reflection does. [Invoking](/wiki/Invoking "Invoking") Itlachiayaque allows the character to create a mass of [poison clouds](/wiki/Poison_cloud "Poison cloud"), similar to a [read](/wiki/Read "Read") [scroll of stinking cloud](/wiki/Scroll_of_stinking_cloud "Scroll of stinking cloud") of the same [beatitude](/wiki/Beatitude "Beatitude"), with the placement of the cloud also depending on your character's role: an Archeologist invoking the Itlachiayaque can center the clouds on a tile within eligible range, while a non-Archeologist invoking the artifact will automatically center the clouds on themselves *unless* it is cursed.

The intended function of Itlachiayaque's invoke effect is for the cloud's position to be controllable if the artifact is non-cursed **and** carried by an Archeologist - a typo in the first line of the effect causes it to behave as described above, and implementations of Itlachiayaque in variants of *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")* generally correct this.

## Strategy

Itlachiayaque effectively exchanges the Orb's [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance") for [reflection](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection"), but at the cost of blocking the player's off-hand for [twoweaponing](/wiki/Twoweapon "Twoweapon") Archeologists and other roles, as well as making [spellcasting](/wiki/Spellcasting "Spellcasting") cumbersome unless a character doffs the shield constantly to cast. Fire resistance, telepathy and half spell damage are welcome, though the former can easily be acquired intrinsically before the quest in most variants. The invoke ability is an improvement on the Orb's [invisibility](/wiki/Invisibility "Invisibility")—the stinking cloud is efficient in clearing masses of enemies that lack poison resistance, and should be useful in [barracks](/wiki/Barracks "Barracks") and [treasure zoos](/wiki/Treasure_zoo "Treasure zoo").

The patch enables quest nemeses to wear artifact armor if possible, and the [Minion of Huhetotl](/wiki/Minion_of_Huhetotl "Minion of Huhetotl") is almost guaranteed to put on the shield: if it does, avoid using ray attacks that can be reflected back at your character.

## Origin

Itlachiayaque is the name of an object, either a mirror or a shield, carried by the Aztec god Tezcatlipoca (whose name literally translates to "fiery mirror").

## List of variants

Below is a list of variants that implement the patch in a different manner, with a link to the article describing that variant's version of the artifact.

### dNetHack

- *Main article: [Itlachiayaque (dNetHack)](/wiki/Itlachiayaque_\(dNetHack\) "Itlachiayaque (dNetHack)")*

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), Itlachiayaque is an [obsidian](/wiki/Obsidian "Obsidian") [roundshield](/wiki/Roundshield "Roundshield") that serves as the Archeologist quest artifact.

### xNetHack

- *Main article: [Itlachiayaque (xNetHack)](/wiki/Itlachiayaque_\(xNetHack\) "Itlachiayaque (xNetHack)")*

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), Itlachiayaque is a [gold](/wiki/Gold_\(material\) "Gold (material)") shield of reflection that serves as the Archeologist quest artifact and can be used as a [crystal ball](/wiki/Crystal_ball "Crystal ball") when invoked in addition to creating poison clouds.

### SlashTHEM

- *Main article: [Itlachiayaque (SlashTHEM)](/wiki/Itlachiayaque_\(SlashTHEM\) "Itlachiayaque (SlashTHEM)")*

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), Itlachiayaque is a shield of reflection that acts as the first [sacrifice gift](/wiki/Sacrifice_gift "Sacrifice gift") for Archeologists, and is the only variation of the artifact to not be intelligent or a quest artifact.

### Hack'EM

- *Main article: [Itlachiayaque (Hack'EM)](/wiki/Itlachiayaque_\(Hack%27EM\) "Itlachiayaque (Hack'EM)")*

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), Itlachiayaque is a gold shield of reflection that serves as the Archeologist quest artifact, and is patterned somewhat after xNetHack's version of the artifact.

## Encyclopedia entry

Tezcatlipoca (Fiery Mirror) was undoubtedly the Jupiter of the  
Nahua pantheon. He carried a mirror or shield \[ Itlachiayaque ],  
from which he took his name, and in which he was supposed to see  
reflected the actions and deeds of mankind. The evolution of this  
god from the status of a spirit of wind or air to that of the  
supreme deity of the Aztec people presents many points of deep  
interest to students of mythology.

\[ The Myths of Mexico and Peru, by Lewis Spence ]
